data.label:
Deivid Wisci

"A very good morning to you, Mr. President. I trust I'm not imposing by arriving ahead of schedule?"

Narrator

As the morning sun streamed through the window of the Presidential Office, an imminent meeting loomed on my agenda. In a quarter of an hour, I was set to discuss the Energy Protection Act of 1932 with Ministers Graf, Holl, and Wisci.

Player

"Given the serious topic we're addressing, an early start might be just what we need."

Player_Italic

I gestured towards the seat.

Narrator

I was sipping my morning coffee and enjoying a quiet moment of solitude when Deivid arrived, characteristically early.

Player

"Not at all, Deivid. On the contrary, we've now got an extra few minutes to strategize before the meeting."

Deivid Wisci

"I appreciate your understanding, Mr. President. It's high time we addressed these pressing matters regarding the EPA."

Deivid Wisci

"I depart earlier for my appointments nowadays, as the stairs of the capital have become more of a challenge than I would like to admit."

Player

"Your wisdom rings true. It's been quite a rollercoaster since the election, hasn't it?"

Player

“The Maroon District and the ministerial buildings are dispersed in a very artificial way. No wonder it takes longer.”

Player

“It's nothing to be ashamed of, Deivid. Would you like some coffee or tea?”

Deivid Wisci

"Reflecting on the years I've spent within these walls is a journey in itself. From the time my father first brought me here during the reign of the King, right up to the present."

Deivid Wisci

"It wasn't always like this, you know. Before Tarquin Soll and his architect Herman Equa gave this area a neo-classical facelift and a new name, it used to be known as the Republic District. "

Deivid Wisci

“I will support you to the end of your term and beyond if my health allows.”

Deivid Wisci

"I trust you're faring well. Sordland is akin to a wild mustang — complex, spirited, and ever elusive to rein in."

Player

"Or perhaps a stubborn mountain goat, unbudging and headstrong."

Deivid Wisci

"A public servant is bound by one principle alone. To serve, to be the voice and hand of the people."

Deivid Wisci

"Listening to the doctor does bring me some comfort. It feels as though my throat has been refreshed thanks to her."

Deivid Wisci

“I will do my best to support you to the end of your term. This country deserves a fresh start and not a descent into the darkness of the distant past.”

Deivid Wisci

"I recall those days with such clarity. The city was a vision of beauty, its people radiant with hope. But the civil war shattered our Sordish Dream, exposing the darkest parts of our nature."

Player

“The longest roads are travelled easier with the dearest fellows.”

Player

“Your expertise is very welcome in this administration. People abroad keep praising you.”

Narrator

He punctuated his statement with a cough, then reached for a glass of water and took a sip.

Deivid Wisci

"You crossed paths with Herman Equa at Holsord State University, didn't you? He was a mentor to many. I recall our discussions about the future at the Kabaret Lachaven, with him and Heron Garaci."

Deivid Wisci

“I know you were just a student at the Deyr University of Culture. Witnessing what true oppression was like.”

Deivid Wisci

"I did not agree with all of the measures enacted by the technocratic government of that era. But some were undeniably effective."

Deivid Wisci

"A mountain goat, you say? Interesting analogy. They are indeed resilient, much like our nation."

Narrator

Just as the conversation hit a pause, the door swung open and the other ministers arrived. Symon Holl entered first with a confident stride.

Player

"Still, one must credit Tarquin Soll for extricating our nation from the ashes."

Player

"Perhaps history would have taken a different course if the Izzam Incident hadn't happened."

Player

"We are deeply indebted to him. The principles of Sollism hold a special place in my heart and continue to guide my decisions."

Player_Italic

I kept listening to him.

Player

"Those were formative years for me. Equa and Garaci left an indelible mark on my outlook."

Player

"It's interesting how those academic days shape our perspectives, isn't it?"

Player

"It was a surreal time, studying business principles while chaos ensued just a few miles away."

Player

"Those disturbances did not deter me from my studies. In fact, they reinforced the importance of my education."

Player

"It was a difficult period. But it was also a reminder of the change I wished to see in Sordland."

Deivid Wisci

"There's merit to that argument. The lingering influence of Soll's traditions may have hampered Alphonso's ability to bring about the changes he envisioned."

Deivid Wisci

"Sollism indeed has its virtues, and it's clear that Soll's legacy continues to resonate with many. The challenge for us is to learn from the past while forging our own path forward."

Deivid Wisci

"It turned us away from the path of reform, but we still worked hard to create the Sordland my father had envisioned."

Deivid Wisci

"Ah. I still remember the first airships in Sordland. We purchased them from Qinal after the war, during the birth of what Soll called the 'Second Republic'."

Player

"It's fascinating to think how much we depended on foreign help after the war. We've come a long way since then."

Player

"The manufacturing of zeppelins in Gelsord was truly a turning point."

Deivid Wisci

"We were in a desperate state then. But remember, it is often in our darkest hours that we find the strength to rise again."

Deivid Wisci

"You're quite right. It symbolized our resilience, our determination to regain our footing. It was a beacon of hope, signaling the revival of our battered industry."

Deivid Wisci

"Our reliance on others was temporary, a stepping stone towards the self-sufficiency we achieved with the National Autarky Plan. Even though it had downsides, I still consider it a success."

Player

"Do you think the EPA still holds relevance today, or should we consider a complete overhaul?"

Player

"The NAP was a cornerstone for our post-war recovery. I wonder, could we have done more with it?"

Deivid Wisci

"Indeed, no policy is immune to misuse. Alphonso's amendments were ambitious, but they also left room for exploitation. We must remain vigilant against such risks."

Narrator

His eyes lingered on the stern face of the old leader. A sigh escaped his lips.

Deivid Wisci

"His visionary zeal succumbed to the more pragmatic, more conservative, and sometimes even regressive, dictates of political survival."

Player

"Life in Holsord back then was tough. Electricity blackouts, ruined infrastructure, unemployment, gangs..."

Deivid Wisci

"It was a challenging period, yes, but we persevered together as a nation."

Deivid Wisci

"Soll's pardons were undoubtedly a contentious move, as they sparked debates about the extent of amnesty granted and the implications for justice."

Deivid Wisci

"Yes, the EPA helped ensure that the sector remained under our control, limiting the extent of ownership of foreign powers such as Rumburg or Lespia."

Deivid Wisci

"In a way, Tarquin Soll did carry on my father's legacy. Under his leadership, we transitioned from a military government to a civilian one, and experienced our first multi-party elections."

Deivid Wisci

“I am sure at least some of my wrinkles today were a direct result of my non-stop debates with them.”

Deivid Wisci

“The minorities of this nation have suffered particularly.”

Player

"Your father's legacy still looms large. Has it influenced your own views?"

Narrator

Deivid turned towards the large, framed portrait of his father, Artor Sanaco Wisci, hanging on the wall. Painted with rich, warm hues, it captured the first President of Sordland in his prime.

Deivid Wisci

"His ability to mobilize public support for revolutionary change has been a constant inspiration to me."

Player

"Sordland wouldn't be what it is today without your father."

Deivid Wisci

"Alphonso, for all his flaws, did seek to set the nation back on a path of progress with his focus on a free market and economic liberalization."

Deivid Wisci

"Welcome, everyone. It's great to see you all here. We have some important discussions on the agenda today, particularly concerning the Energy Protection Act."

Player

"Indeed, it's a critical issue that we need to address. I look forward to hearing everyone's perspectives."

Symon Holl

"Today, we have the opportunity to shape the economic strategy of Sordland for decades to come. The EPA has long stood as a key contention and debate point of the National Autarky Plan."

Symon Holl

"The President's decision to foster a planned economy provides us with significant insight into our policy direction."

Symon Holl

"Mr. President has decided to lean on promoting a market economy, which should give us a clear indicator."

Deivid Wisci

"I respect the decision of the Assembly, Lileas. However, we mustn't allow this setback to deter us from exploring the best possible options for Sordland. The global landscape is ever-evolving and we must adapt accordingly."

Player

"A fair point, Lileas. We must respect the decision of the Assembly, even if it doesn't align with our own views."

Player

"It's disappointing to see the Assembly resist change this much. Our debate is definitely not over."

Symon Holl

"When it comes to the Energy Protection Act, I believe we should consider complete removal. If not, at the very least, we should increase the threshold to 49 percent."

Deivid Wisci

"What if we increased the limit to 49 percent, thereby attracting foreign investment while maintaining Sordish control over critical energy sectors?"

Player

"Considering potential foreign buyers such as Qinal, Rizia, Anraka, Rumburg, and Lespia, what are the worst-case scenarios if they gain control over our hydroelectric, gas, and oil sectors?"

Player

"How would the Energy Protection Act changes impact corporations like Gasom, which could sell to any entity under the revised laws?"

Player

"Lileas, you mentioned national security risks. Could you elaborate further on that?"

Symon Holl

"The scenarios Lileas mentioned are possible, of course, but think about the economic growth and international relations that could be fostered."

Lileas Graf

"I believe you already know the answer to this, Mr. President."

Deivid Wisci

"There's no denying the potential risks of foreign buyers gaining control over critical sectors."

Deivid Wisci

"National security risks are always a concern when discussing foreign ownership. That's why it's crucial to have thorough vetting and monitoring processes in place."

Deivid Wisci

"With increased foreign investment, we could potentially see a decrease in energy prices."

Lileas Graf

"The national security risks are significant. Foreign entities could use their stake in our energy sector as leverage in diplomatic or economic negotiations."

Symon Holl

"Yes, Gasom could potentially sell to anyone, but wouldn't that be a testament to the strength and attractiveness of our energy sector on the global stage?"

Lileas Graf

"Changing the Energy Protection Act could lead to increased energy prices, as foreign entities could manipulate the market."

Symon Holl

"With increased competition and foreign investment, we could also see a decrease in energy prices. The more players in the market, the more competitive the prices will be."

Lileas Graf

"I firmly believe in the sovereignty and strength of our nation."

Deivid Wisci

"Given the turbulent economic landscape, maintaining the status quo of the Energy Protection Act could offer us stability."

Symon Holl

"Increasing foreign investment could significantly stimulate our economy."

EPA Questions Hub

EPA Questions Hub

Player

"Let's remove the Energy Protection Act entirely. We need to drastically open up our energy economy to the world."

Symon Holl

"Should we decide to increase the EPA threshold to 49 percent or eliminate it entirely, it could spark an influx of foreign investment."

Lileas Graf

"A planned economy does not necessarily mean restricting foreign investment. It's about judicious management and control, ensuring that our nation's interests are always at the forefront."

Symon Holl

"We must remember that Sordland was facing an economic crisis during his tenure, and these changes provided a lifeline for our energy industries."

Player

"Wasn't this change a sign of desperation rather than a strategic move?"

Player

"But did the increased foreign ownership actually lead to substantial economic growth?"

Player

"I must confess, when the changes to the Energy Protection Act were first implemented, I harbored serious reservations."

Deivid Wisci

"It facilitated foreign investment and provided our industries with much-needed capital. The effects of such policy changes often take time to fully manifest, but they lay the groundwork for future economic development."

Deivid Wisci

"However, it's crucial to remember that policy-making often involves balancing competing interests and making tough decisions. The goal was, and remains, to advance Sordland's economy while protecting our strategic interests."

Deivid Wisci

"The economic crisis during Alphonso's tenure did necessitate action, but we should not view the change to the Energy Protection Act as simply a desperate measure."

Deivid Wisci

"While the increase in foreign ownership alone didn't lead to a drastic upturn in economic growth, it did have a positive effect."

Deivid Wisci

"Your reservations were not unfounded. It was indeed a significant change and, as with any policy shift, it brought about its share of controversies and criticisms."

Player

"You present a compelling argument, Lileas. It's certainly an aspect we must consider moving forward."

Lileas Graf

"I appreciate your kind words, Mr. President. It's our shared dedication to Sordland that drives us."

Lileas Graf

"I think you are misguided in this way of thinking. But of course we're allowed to hold differing opinions."

Lileas Graf

"Thank you, Mr. President. It's crucial to consider all angles in matters as important as this."

Lileas Graf

"Promoting a market economy does not inherently translate to prosperity for all. It can lead to a concentration of wealth, with the rich getting richer while the middle and working classes struggle."

Player

"I couldn't agree more, Lileas. The welfare of our citizens should be our primary concern."

Lileas Graf

"I'm glad we see eye to eye on this matter, Mr. President. Our welfare as a whole depends on that of the least fortunate among us."

Lileas Graf

"I understand your point of view, Mr. President. But we must also consider the potential pitfalls of unregulated capitalism."

Lileas Graf

"Thank you, Mr. President. It's indeed crucial to consider all possibilities when making decisions of this magnitude."

Symon Holl

"Our current version of the Energy Protection Act dates back to 1949. President Alphonso's amendment raised the cap on foreign investment in Sordish energy companies up to 20 percent."

Symon Holl

"A careful increase to 49 percent could be a balanced compromise, signaling to the world that Sordland is open for business, while still retaining majority control of our assets."

Lileas Graf

"Returning the threshold to 10 percent, as it was during the Soll era, could protect us from undue foreign influence and ensure that our energy sector remains in Sordish hands."

Deivid Wisci

"We are already open to foreign investment at a 20 percent threshold. Changing this percentage may introduce unexpected challenges and could complicate our foreign relations."

Player

"We will increase the foreign ownership threshold to 49 percent. This will increase foreign investment."

Player

"Let's keep the Energy Protection Act as it is. The status quo has worked so far."

Player

"We are returning the foreign ownership limit to 10 percent, as it was in the Soll era."

Symon Holl

"This has the potential to spur significant economic growth."

Deivid Wisci

"That's a bold decision, Mr. President."

Lileas Graf

"I fear this compromises our national energy sovereignty."

Symon Holl

"This could attract significant foreign investment."

Deivid Wisci

"A balanced approach will serve us well."

Lileas Graf

"It's a substantial increase. I fear we are opening ourselves up too much. "

Symon Holl

"It's a safe choice, though it might limit our economic growth."

Lileas Graf

"It may not be what Soll would have wanted, but it is a prudent decision."

Symon Holl

"It's a conservative approach and it will limit our potential for growth. I will work hard to reduce the impact on our energy industry."

Deivid Wisci

"This will send a strong message of self-reliance."

Narrator

The door to the room opened. Livia Suno carried a tray laden with an assortment of beverages.

Player

"Thank you, Livia. A coffee for me, please."

Player

"Appreciate it, Livia. Tea would be perfect now."

Player

"Just water for me, Livia. Thanks."

Livia Suno

"Of course, Mr. President. Here you are."

Livia Suno

"Very well, Mr. President. Here's your tea."

Livia Suno

"Certainly, Mr. President. Here's your water."

Narrator

The meeting resumed, our conversation growing slightly louder over the clink of cups and glasses.

Player

"Please be more considerate and ask before you enter next time."

Symon Holl

"I share your sentiments, Mr. President. However, we must be careful to avoid encouraging anti-business tendencies."

Lileas Graf

"I concur, Mr. President. Ensuring the rights of our workers is paramount, although we must be cautious of any hidden agendas."

Player

"Your collaboration with Mr. Beniwoll is commendable. I hope it will bring about a positive change for our workforce."

Player

"Workers' rights are important, but we need to ensure that the bill doesn't introduce excessive regulations that could stifle our businesses."

Player

"I will reserve my judgment until I have a chance to review the bill in detail."

Deivid Wisci

"Thank you, Mr. President. The bill aims to prioritize workers' wellbeing. It's a step towards a more humane economic system."

Deivid Wisci

"I understand your concerns, Mr. President. We are aiming to strike a balance between workers' rights and business needs."

Deivid Wisci

"Absolutely, Mr. President. We will ensure you receive the bill for review as soon as possible."

Symon Holl

"Agreed. The last thing we need is to overburden our businesses with regulations."

Symon Holl

"It's important not to decide these things too hastily. Don't let emotions cloud your judgement."

Lileas Graf

"That's never a concern with you, is it, Mr. Holl?"

Symon Holl

"Specifically, we're considering a range of 10 percent tax changes for small-to-medium enterprises and large corporations. This could be a significant move for our economic landscape."

Symon Holl

"I appreciate your insight, Mr. President. Ensuring the survival and growth of our SMEs is at the forefront of our considerations."

Symon Holl

"Your caution is well-placed, Mr. President."

Deivid Wisci

"Tax changes could indeed have a significant impact on our economy. We must consider their implications carefully."

Deivid Wisci

"As a proponent of global trade and economic cooperation, I too believe we should be cautious about imposing excessive taxes on businesses."

Player

"I'm very satisfied that we are executing bold changes under this administration."

Lileas Graf

"In light of the economic challenges we face, increasing taxation could provide much-needed revenue to support crucial public services and social welfare programs."

Lileas Graf

"To me, promoting growth comes secondary to holding corporations accountable."

Lileas Graf

"Meanwhile, Mr. President, I've heard about the plans for the Emergency Act. I believe it is a necessary step in ensuring the security and stability of Sordland."

Lileas Graf

"I understand your concern, Mr. President. I assure you, I will handle this task with utmost care."

Lileas Graf

"Of course, Mr. President. You will be updated about every step we take."

Symon Holl

"I appreciate your diligence. Let's hope that the impact on our economy will be minimal."

Symon Holl

"The Emergency Act is a serious measure indeed. It's good to know you're handling it."

Symon Holl

"Keep the economic consequences in mind as you proceed, Lileas. We need to maintain a balance."

Deivid Wisci

"Handle it carefully, Lileas. We need to ensure the Emergency Act doesn't harm our diplomatic relations."

Deivid Wisci

"And please keep us informed. We all need to be in the loop."

Narrator

As the ministers rose from their seats, the late-morning light spilled into the room through the ornate windows.

Player

"Thank you all for your insights and collaboration today. Have a great afternoon."

Player

"Our unity is our strength. Let's continue to work together for the good of Sordland."

Player

"We've made some important decisions today. Let's wrap up for now and reconvene later if needed."

Player

"Our work is our legacy. Let's make sure it's one that Sordland can be proud of."

Lileas Graf

"Thank you for the discussion. I'll continue working on our priorities. Goodbye, everyone."

Deivid Wisci

"I believe it's crucial to ensure fair treatment for our workforce. And it is nearing presentation."

Player

"I heavily disagreed with the move at the time. Even as executive Vice President in 1946, Alphonso simply tried to change the country too fast."

Player

"First it was the State Educators Corps, then the SSC Bills, and then slowly the EPA. He wanted to erase every trace of Tarquin Soll's Second Republic."

Lileas Graf

"Gasom could fall under foreign control, just like any other energy corporation."

Deivid Wisci

"If we increase the foreign ownership threshold to 49%, we can attract more investments while mitigating those risks."

Deivid Wisci

"But we should also consider the potential impact on job security and national control of our energy sector."

Symon Holl

"While we may see entities from Qinal, Rizia, Anraka, Rumburg, or Lespia as potential threats, it's also crucial to see them as potential partners."

Symon Holl

"And those resources could be channeled into further development of our energy sector."

Lileas Graf

"I caution against drastic changes that may leave us vulnerable to foreign influence. We must maintain control of our energy sector at all costs."

Lileas Graf

"Our investment in Gasom reinforces Sordland's sovereignty. However, altering the EPA may dilute that sovereignty."

Deivid Wisci

"Considering we're investing heavily in Gasom, our decision about the EPA will greatly impact the attractiveness of the remaining shares to foreign investors."

Lileas Graf

"However, if we raise the foreign ownership threshold, we must be wary of the influence of Rumburg."

Lileas Graf

"Sharing the burden with Rizia does provide some reassurance."

Deivid Wisci

"With Sordland and Rizia co-investing in Gasom, there's a chance to build a partnership that benefits both our economies. However, how we adjust the EPA could significantly impact the outcome."

Lileas Graf

"Having Rizia as the sole investor already compromises our energy independence to a certain extent."

Player

"Considering Rizia's investment, we could stick with the current threshold. This way, we minimize foreign interference while keeping our energy sector financially stable."

Player

"Raising the threshold could attract more investors. However, we must be careful to avoid losing control of our resources."

Player

"Our partnership with Rizia has proven beneficial. I suggest we maintain the current threshold. Let's not make hasty decisions that might disrupt this balance."

Player

"Perhaps we should consider removing the threshold altogether. It could propel Gasom into the global market and truly maximize our gains."

Player

"If we keep the foreign ownership threshold as is, we're limiting foreign investment. However, our 30 percent stake in Gasom would remain significant and protected."

Player

"By reducing the foreign ownership limit to 10 percent, we're closing off most foreign investment opportunities. This ensures our 30 percent stake in Gasom holds significant power."

Deivid Wisci

"On the other hand, foreign investment would result in increased resources flowing to Gasom and its ilk."

Player

"By increasing the foreign ownership threshold to 49 percent, we're opening up more opportunities for foreign investment. This could improve the value of our own 30 percent stake in Gasom."

Player

"While your points are valid, Lileas, we can't ignore the potential economic benefits. Raising the threshold could attract more investors and increase the value of our shares."

Player

"Let's consider lowering the threshold back to 10 percent. This could ensure more Sordish control over Gasom and safeguard our energy independence."

Symon Holl

"I would say we've covered the implications of your EPA decision fairly thoroughly, Mr. President."

Lileas Graf

"Raising the threshold to 49 percent could increase Gasom's value, and by extension the value of our 30 percent stake. But we don't want to lose control over the company."

Symon Holl

"A 49 percent threshold could increase the value of our stake without risking loss of control."

Deivid Wisci

"Increasing the EPA to 49% opens up a new avenue of trade, but we will have to ensure our national interests are not compromised."

Player

"We have to consider the long-term impact of our decisions. Foreign investment might bring immediate financial gains, but we'd risk losing control of our energy sector."

Symon Holl

"But would we be missing out on potential growth?"

Lileas Graf

"Reducing the threshold to 10 percent would be my preference. It allows for the possibility for foreign investment while preserving Sordish sovereignty."

Symon Holl

"On the other hand, it would deter foreign investors, which would make a dent in the company's profitability and shrink our returns."

Lileas Graf

"Maintaining the current threshold is a safe option, but my preference would be 10 percent default imposed in the Soll era. It will limit opportunities in the long run, but our state will perservere."

Lileas Graf

"President, I must express my strong disagreement. Complete removal of the threshold means we would lose control over our own resources to foreign powers. It's too high a price for questionable economic benefits."

Symon Holl

"Removing the threshold is indeed an ambitious move, Mr. President. It could lead to a significant influx of foreign investment and boost our economy. However, we must be prepared to manage the associated risks and ensure our interests are not compromised."

Deivid Wisci

"A full removal, while certainly bold, could dramatically shift our international trade dynamics. It would also require us to navigate the complexities of increased foreign relations and potential dependency."

Lileas Graf

"I understand the potential economic benefits, but we can't compromise our sovereignty for profits."

Player

"We should be more aggressive in attracting foreign investment. After all, a thriving energy sector can be a major driver of our economic growth."

Lileas Graf

"Maintaining the status quo might indeed be the safest choice in this scenario. We need to protect our energy sector from becoming a playground for foreign powers."

Deivid Wisci

"Maintaining the status quo could provide stability in our relations with Rizia, but it might also limit our potential to attract additional foreign investment."

Symon Holl

"If we manage the risks effectively, raising the threshold could indeed provide a significant boost to our economy."

Deivid Wisci

"Raising the threshold could potentially boost our economy, but it could also complicate our relations with other foreign powers, including Rumburg."

Deivid Wisci

"Lowering the threshold could send a strong message of our commitment to national sovereignty, but it could also deter foreign investors."

Symon Holl

"Lowering the threshold might limit foreign investment, but it could also safeguard our energy sector from foreign exploitation."

Lileas Graf

"Returning to the 10 percent threshold would be a step in the right direction. It will ensure that Sordland remains in control of its own resources."

Player

"Our choices aren't just about the numbers. They hold significant implications for the people of Sordland. We must make our decision with them in mind."

Player

"The EPA has been a safeguard for our national interests, but we must also be open to change. We need to carefully weigh the benefits and drawbacks."

Deivid Wisci

"However, it's worth acknowledging that by offering clemency, Soll aimed to provide an opportunity for healing and reconciliation in a divided society."

Deivid Wisci

"Despite the controversies, it was crucial to our recovery and has helped us maintain our energy independence to this day."

Player

"The future of our gas industry lies in our hands, not anyone else's. Our full investment in Gasom is a testament to our resolve."

Player

"By investing alone, we've seized significant control of the private gas sector. This aligns with our goal of nationalizing key industries. We must ensure this doesn't strain our economy."

Player

"This investment signifies our commitment to Sordland's energy independence. Let's put our resources to work for the Sordish people."

Player

"A joint venture with Rizia is a strategic move, not a concession. It's a partnership that secures our place in the global energy landscape."

Player

"Sharing investment responsibilities with Rizia may ease our financial load, but it also means we've invited foreign influence into our energy sector. We must tread carefully."

Player

"Our partnership with Rizia is a testament to our commitment to regional cooperation. It's a pragmatic move that will be beneficial for both nations."

Player

"There's wisdom in caution. Let's keep our options open and observe Rizia's approach. Our time to invest will come."

Player

"Our decision not to invest at this time is not a withdrawal but a strategic pause. We will decide when the time is right."

Narrator

Symon meticulously adjusted his glasses.

Symon Holl

"One more concern. Gus and Mikail informed me that you have given President Alphonso assurances about not imposing stricter EPA regulations."

Player

"There is no need to be destructive in an already dangerous economy that could spiral downward."

Player

"I understand the need for economic stability. But I'm reconsidering my promise now that I know all the facts."

Symon Holl

"We must consider the far-reaching implications of our actions. Today's decisions regarding the EPA will significantly impact Gasom and other corporations in the future."

Symon Holl

"Regarding Gasom, our decision to invest alone certainly places us in more control over the gas sector. This could be beneficial, but it has increased our financial burden significantly. We must review our fiscal policies."

Symon Holl

"Regarding Gasom, our co-investment with Rizia allows us to distribute the financial burden and mitigate risks. This decision promotes regional cooperation, aligning well with our fiscal policies."

Symon Holl

"Regarding Gasom, our decision not to invest  may be seen as a cautious move. It has certainly reduced our immediate financial responsibilities, but we may have missed an opportunity."

Player

"Our administration needs to protect the jobs of Gasom workers and this investment ensures that. I have little interest beyond this."

Player

"Rizia might not be the best partner given our history with them, but we have to take a balanced approach with our budget and economy."

Player

"By allowing Rizia to monopolize the energy sector, we've indirectly promoted capitalist exploitation. We must remain vigilant and ensure our people are not subjugated to foreign profiteering."

Deivid Wisci

"A reduction in the EPA could pave the way for potential profits from shares, whereas total removal may invite an unpredictable rush for the remaining 45%."

Player

"If we remove the Energy Protection Act entirely, our 30 percent investment could potentially be overshadowed by foreign investors. However, it could also maximize our returns if foreign investment floods in."

Lileas Graf

"Full removal of the EPA is a risk. Foreign investors could buy up larger stakes than our own. We might lose control over Gasom."

Deivid Wisci

"Foreign influence in Gasom, if not managed correctly, could lead to a dilution of Sordland's control in the energy sector."

Player

"Even though we're sharing the investment with Rizia, we should still prioritize Sordish control. Let's consider reducing the foreign ownership limit."

Symon Holl

"Reducing the foreign ownership limit might safeguard our control, but it could limit our potential for economic growth."

Player

"We could remove the threshold entirely, opening up to more foreign investment. But we'd need to be prepared for all the diplomatic consequences that may follow."

Deivid Wisci

"It could also lead to a volatile situation in terms of our foreign relations."

Symon Holl

"Full removal of the threshold is an extremely bold move. It could lead to a significant increase in foreign investment, but we must also consider the risks."

Lileas Graf

"Total removal of the threshold is a dangerous proposition. It would make us vulnerable to foreign influence and could lead to the loss of our energy independence."

Player

"Our priority should be balancing the need for economic growth with maintaining national sovereignty. Perhaps a phased approach to increasing foreign ownership could be the answer."

Symon Holl

"Mr. President, it's time for us to make a decision. What will we do with the EPA?"

Player

"We need to balance our commitment to Alphonso with the needs of our nation."

Player

"There's also the matter of international perception. We should be careful not to appear as if we're making policy based on corporate interests alone."

Symon Holl

"I foresee difficult conversations ahead with the National Business Council and President Alphonso."

Player

"I'd like to clear my mind before the ministers arrive."

Narrator

Then the door swung open, ushering in the arrival of the other ministers. Symon Holl entered first with a confident stride.

Narrator

It was nice to sit in silence and enjoy each other's company. Time passed.

Deivid Wisci

"I believe much of his urgency was motivated by his own desire to escape Soll's shadow. For better or worse, he managed it."

Symon Holl

"Mr. President, Lileas, shall we return to the subject of the EPA?"

Symon Holl

"In my view, it was a necessary step to attract foreign investment and stimulate our economy."

Lileas Graf

"Think about it, Mr. President. If any one of those countries -- but especially Rumburg -- gains control of our energy sector, they could cut off our power at any moment."

Lileas Graf

"We would also be forced to comply with any decision they made regarding prices or environmental measures."

Symon Holl

"Don't forget about the importance of economic security. In a globalized world, economic strength can be just as critical as military might."

Deivid Wisci

"At times the window of change is only very small. And now that you and I are in the cabinet, we can promote the change we truly advocate for."

Player

"While I respect your stance, Lileas, I must disagree."

Player

"I share your view. Soll's old policy was choking the growth of Sordish energy businesses."

Deivid Wisci

"Many others also saw Alphonso's changes as necessary. Though they did not pass without a great deal of controversy."

Player

"I don't only respect the Assembly's decision. I wholeheartedly support it."
